questions.question: A 6-month old baby was brought to the clinic with the following finding. Which among the following statements is incorrect regarding the likely diagnosis?

options.C: Oral propranolol can be used for treating this condition
options.D: Most common orbital tumor of children.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) More common in boys Explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Capillary Hemangioma . Description Most common orbital tumor in children (Option D) More common in girls than boys ( 3:2 ratio ) (Option A) Onset & Growth Visible at birth in about one-third of cases Rapid growth phase in the first 6 months ~75% regress by 7 years old spontaneously (Option B) Appearance Red, raised nodular mass

questions.question: Match the image with the condition: Image Condition a. Chronic painless swelling 1. Stye b. Acute painful swelling 2. Chalazion c. Acute painful Swelling 3. Hordeolum Internum
Which is the most common organism causing bacterial blepharitis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Staphylococci Explanation: Staphylococci is the most common organism causing bacterial blepharitis Bacterial blepharitis: Definition Chronic infection of the anterior part of the lid margin Synonyms Chronic anterior blepharitis Staphylococcal blepharitis Causative Organisms Most commonly Staphylococci (coagulase positive) Rarely Streptococci, Propionibacterium acnes, and Moraxella Clinical Features Chronic irritation Itching Mild lacrimation Gluing of cilia Mild photophobia Yellow crusts at the root of cilia Small ulcers that bleed easily when crusts are removed Red, thickened lid margins with dilated blood vessels Mild papillary conjunctivitis and conjunctival hyperemia Treatment Lid Hygiene: Warm compresses Cotton buds dipped in dilute baby shampoo or 3% sodium bicarbonate solution Avoid touching Antibiotics Topical Steroids Ocular Lubricants Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology 9th edition page 70-72

questions.question: A 3-year-old girl has been having difficulty opening her left eye since birth. An image is given below. What is the condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ankyloblepharon Explanation: The scenario is of adhesion of upper and lower lid - ankyloblepharon Condition Definition Etiology Symblepharon Palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva adhesions. Healing of raw surfaces on the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva. Causes: Thermal or chemical burns, membranous conjunctivitis, injuries, conjunctival ulcerations, ocular pemphigus, Stevens-Johnson syndrome. Ankyloblepharon Adhesions between the margins of the upper and lower eyelids. Congenital anomaly. Acquired adhesions after healing of chemical burns, thermal burns, ulcers, and traumatic wounds of the lid margins. Often associated with symblepharon.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman with hypothyroidism is now complaining of loss of eyelashes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Madarosis Explanation: The scenario is of loss of eyelashes (madarosis) secondary to hypothyroidism Condition Definition Local Causes Systemic Causes Madarosis (Option A) Partial or complete loss of eyelashes or eyebrows. Chronic blepharitis Cicatrizing conjunctivitis Complications from cryotherapy, radiotherapy, or surgery for eyelid lesions Alopecia Psoriasis Hypothyroidism Leprosy Systemic lupus erythematosus Acquired syphilis Poliosis (Option B) Greying of eyelashes and eyebrows. Chronic anterior blepharitis Sympathetic ophthalmitis Idiopathic uveitis Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome Waardenburg syndrome Vitiligo Marfan syndrome Tuberous sclerosis Tylosis (Option C) - thickening and scarring of the lid margin, a complication of long-standing bacterial blepharitis

questions.question: A neonatologist has noted the following finding in a newborn baby. What is the condition called?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Distichiasis Explanation: The case is of distichiasis - extra eyelash row Eyelash rubbing the cornea can happen in: Trichiasis - I nward misdirection of lashes with the normal position of the lid margin (Option A ruled out) Pseudotrichiasis - Inward turning of lashes along with the lid margin (Option B ruled out) Distichiasis - Extra row of eyelash (Option C) Clinical features Foreign body sensation Photophobia Irritation Pain Lacrimation Reflex blepharospasm and photophobia (if the cornea is abraded) Conjunctival congestion Complications Recurrent corneal abrasions Superficial corneal opacities Corneal vascularization Non-healing corneal ulcer Treatment Epilation Electrolysis Cryoepilation Surgical correction

questions.question: A 70-year-old patient presents with complaints of epiphora. On examination, there is an eversion of the punctum noted. Which among the following is incorrect regarding the type of ectropion seen in this patient?

options.C: Age-related changes are implicated in etiopathogenesis
options.D: Starts from lateral eyelid and progresses medially

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Starts from lateral eyelid and progresses medially Explanation: The given clinical scenario is indicative of involutional ectropion . Involutional ectropion: Most common form (Option A) Caused by age-related laxity of lower eyelid structures. (Option C) It usually begins medially and extends laterally . (Option D) Progression leads to: Conjunctival inflammation, Keratinization, Lagophthalmos (Option B) Type of Ectropion Description Causes Clinical Features Treatment Involutional Ectropion Most common; age-related Horizontal laxity Canthal tendon laxity Epiphora Tarsal thinning Lagophthalmos Medial conjunctivoplasty for mild cases. Horizontal lid shortening for moderate cases. Byron Smith's modified Kuhnt-Szymanowski operation for severe cases. Lateral tarsal strip technique for generalized ectropion. Cicatricial Ectropion Scarring of anterior lamella Trauma/surgery Scarring conditions (e.g., blepharitis) Scarring Skin fibrosis Mild cases: V-Y operation. Mild to moderate cases: Z-plasty (Elschnig's operation). Severe cases: Excision of scar tissue and full-thickness skin grafting. Paralytic Ectropion Facial nerve palsy (Bell’s) Bell’s palsy Trauma/surgery Exposure keratopathy Temporary measures: Topical lubricants, eyelid taping, suture tarsorrhaphy. Permanent measures (if needed): Horizontal lid tightening with/without middle lamellar buttress, palpebral sling operation. Mechanical Ectropion Mass or lesion pushing eyelid Tumors Conjunctival growths Eyelid displacement Conjunctival chemosis Treat the underlying mechanical causes. Congenital Ectropion Present at birth Tarsal plate atrophy Down syndrome Associated eyelid malformation Mild cases may not require treatment. Moderate or severe cases: Horizontal lid tightening and full-thickness skin graft. Grading of Ectropion: GRADE FEATURE 0 Normal eyelid appearance and function I Only punctum is everted II Lid margin everted and palpebral conjunctiva visible III Fornix is also visible Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology. 5th Edition, Page 1287,1288

questions.question: Match the following types of entropion with their correct pair 1) Mechanical entropion A) Trachoma 2) Cicatricial entropion B) Phthisis bulbi 3) Congenital entropion C) Senile entropion 4) Involutional entropion D) Most commonly involves lower eyelid
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C Explanation: 1) Mechanical entropion B) Phthisis bulbi 2) Cicatricial entropion A) Trachoma 3) Congenital entropion D) Most commonly involves lower eyelid 4) Involutional entropion C) Senile entropion Types of Entropion: Type Description Etiology 1) Congenital Entropion Present since birth, more common in the lower eyelid Lower Eyelid: Improper development of lower lid retractors. Upper Eyelid: Mechanical effects due to microphthalmos. 2) Cicatricial Entropion Commonly involves the upper eyelid. Common causes: Trachoma , chemical burns, pemphigus, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, symblepharon. 3) Senile (Involutional) Entropion Affects the lower eyelid in elderly individuals . Horizontal lid laxity Vertical lid instability Overriding of pretarsal orbicularis. Laxity of orbital septum 4) Mechanical Entropion Lack of support from the globe to the lids. Occurs in conditions like phthisis bulbi , enophthalmos and after enucleation or evisceration operations. Reference: Yanoff & Duker - Ophthalmology 5th edition, page 1281 Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology 9th edition page 85-87

questions.question: A 75-year-old male patient presents with the following ocular findings and complaints of watering and photophobia. On examination, there are signs of minimal horizontal lid laxity. Which of the following surgical procedures would be the most appropriate for a long-term correction of his condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Weis procedure Explanation: The patient’s symptoms of watering and photophobia, along with the image of an inward-turned lower lid margin, suggest entropion . The most appropriate surgical procedure for correcting entropion with minimal horizontal laxity is the Weis procedure . Involutional Entropion: Description and etiology Usually seen in lower eyelid in elderly people Horizontal lid laxity due to weakening of orbicularis muscle Vertical lid instability due to weakening of capsulopalpebral fascia Overriding of pretarsal orbicularis/Laxity of orbital septum Clinical features Foreign body sensation Lacrimation Photophobia Horizontal lid laxity Surgical Techniques i. Transverse Suture and Everting Suture: (Option A) Temporary cure (up to 18 months) Suitable for very old patients ii. Weis procedure: (Option B) Long-term cure with minimal horizontal lid laxity iii. Plication of Lower Lid Retractors (Jones Operation): (Option C) Used in severe cases or after recurrence Shortens lower lid retractors. iv. Quickert Procedure: (Option D) For cases with marked horizontal lid laxity Combines horizontal lid shortening with Weis procedure Grading of Entropion: Grade-I Only the posterior lid border is in-rolled Grade-II includes in-rolling up to the intermarginal strip Grade-III Whole lid margin including the anterior border is in-rolled Complications include recurrent corneal abrasions, superficial

questions.question: Which among the following structures is part of the anterior lamella of the eyelid?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Orbicularis oculi Explanation: The lid is made up of mainly thick connective tissue, which is called tarsal plate. The eyelid is divided by a grey line into anterior and posterior lamella: Anterior lamella structures include skin, subcutaneous tissue and orbicularis oculi (Option A) . Posterior lamella structures include tarsal plate (Option C) and conjunctiva (Option D) . The space between supraorbital margin and infraorbital margin is filled by a thin connective tissue known as orbital septum (Option B) . Reference: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6486383/

questions.question: All are causes of ipsilateral pseudoptosis except
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lid retraction Explanation: Pseudoptosis: Apparent drooping of eyelid, unrelated to neurological or muscular abnormalities. Causes of pseudoptosis: Ipsilateral pseudoptosis Contralateral pseudoptosis Microphthalmos Enophthalmos (Option A) Phthisis bulbi (Option D) Hypotropia (Option C) Dermatochalasis Eyelid retraction (Option B) High myopia Proptosis Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology 9th edition page 75

questions.question: Which of the following measurements is considered indicative of moderate ptosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 3 mm droop Explanation: Measurement of the degree of Ptosis: In unilateral cases, the difference in the vertical height of the palpebral fissures on the two sides indicates the degree of ptosis. In bilateral cases, measure the amount of cornea covered by the upper lid and subtract 2mm. Ptosis grading Mild Ptosis 2mm droop Moderate Ptosis 3mm droop Severe Ptosis 4mm droop Margin reflex distance (MRD) MRD 1: Distance between the upper lid margins and corneal light reflex. The normal value is 4-4.5mm. MRD 2: Distance between the pupillary reflex in the centre to the lower lid margin. Normal values 5 - 5.5mm. Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology 9th edition page 75 MRD 1&2

questions.question: Which muscle is most commonly affected in congenital ptosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Levator palpebrae superioris Explanation: Congenital Ptosis: Associated with congenital weakness or maldevelopment of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) muscle. Congenital ptosis probably results from a failure of neuronal migration or development with muscular sequelae secondary to this. A minority of patients have a family history. Characteristic features: Drooping of one or both upper lids. Lid crease is either diminished or absent. Lid lag on downgaze due to tethering effect of abnormal LPS muscle. Types of congenital ptosis: 1. Simple congenital ptosis: Unilateral or bilateral Non-progressive No fluctuation: Unlike myogenic ptosis, congenital ptosis does not worsen throughout the day or improve with rest. 2. Congenital ptosis with associated weakness of superior rectus muscle. 3. Blepharophimosis syndrome: Congenital ptosis Blepharophimosis Telecanthus Epicanthus inversus. 4. Congenital synkinetic ptosis (Marcus Gunn jaw-winking ptosis) Retraction of the ptotic lid with jaw movements due to stimulation of ipsilateral pterygoid muscle. It occurs due to trigemino-oculomotor synkinesis. The pathophysiology of Marcus Gunn Jaw winking phenomenon is a congenital misdirection of mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve, i.e., this synkinetic movement results from a congenital aberrant connection between motor branches of the trigeminal nerve controlling muscles of mastication and superior division of the oculomotor nerve controlling the levator palpebrae superioris. Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Page 77,78 Congenital ptosis

questions.question: Which of the following is a distinguishing feature of aponeurotic ptosis compared to other forms of ptosis?

options.B: Presents with normal function of the levator muscle
options.C: Results from a neurological condition affecting the third cranial nerve
options.D: Usually involves a sudden onset of symptoms

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Presents with normal function of the levator muscle Explanation: Acquired Aponeurotic Ptosis: Develops due to defect of levator aponeurosis in the presence of a normal functioning muscle. Also known as involutional ptosis. It includes: Senile Ptosis Postoperative Ptosis Ptosis associated with blepharochalasis. Traumatic dehiscence or disinsertion of aponeurosis. Accompanied by ocular motor dysfunction (Option A): Aponeurotic ptosis is not associated with ocular motor dysfunction, which is more common in neurological forms of ptosis. Results from a neurological condition affecting the third cranial nerve (Option C): This describes ptosis due to cranial nerve III palsy, not aponeurotic ptosis. Usually involves a sudden onset of symptoms (Option D): Aponeurotic ptosis generally has a gradual onset rather than sudden, distinguishing it from other types of ptosis that may present more abruptly. Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology 9th edition page 74

questions.question: A 45-year-old female presents with bilateral ptosis that worsens throughout the day, particularly in the evening, and improves with rest. She also complains of double vision and generalized fatigue. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Myasthenia gravis Explanation: Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder characterized by weakness in voluntary muscles, which worsens with activity and improves with rest. It often presents with ptosis, diplopia, and generalized muscle weakness. Myogenic ptosis is caused by a myopathy of the levator muscle itself, or by impairment of transmission of impulses at the neuromuscular junction (neuromyopathic). Acquired Myogenic Ptosis: Occurs due to acquired disorders of the LPS muscle or the myoneural junction. Acquired myogenic ptosis occurs in myasthenia gravis, myotonic dystrophy and progressive external ophthalmoplegia It is seen in conditions like: Myasthenia gravis (M/C) Dystrophia myotonica Ocular myopathy Oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy Thyrotoxicosis Lambert Eaton myasthenic syndrome Trauma to LPS muscle Horner's Syndrome (Option A): Mild, constant ptosis which does not worsen with activity or improve with rest and no generalized fatigue or double vision. Oculopharyngeal Muscular Dystrophy (OPMD) (Option C): Progressive, constant ptosis but no fluctuation or improvement with rest and no daily variation in symptoms. Botulism (Option D): Sudden onset of ptosis.Symptoms do not improve with rest and not associated with daily fluctuation Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology 9th edition page 74

questions.question: A 60-year old male, heavy smoker, presents with persistent shoulder pain radiating to arm for several months. He presents with the following ocular findings. A chest x-ray reveals mass at the apex of the left lung. Which of the following symptoms is most likely to accompany this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Anhydrosis and miosis Explanation: The given clinical vignette suggests that the patient most likely has Horner’s syndrome , which can result from a Pancoast tumor at the apex of the lung. This tumor can compress the sympathetic nerves, leading to the classic triad of symptoms: ptosis, miosis (constricted

questions.question: Identify the structure marked ‘X’ in the given image.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Tarsal plate Explanation: The structure ‘X’ is the tarsal plate which belongs to the posterior lamella of the eyelid. The eyelid is divided by a gray line into anterior and posterior lamella: Anterior lamella Posterior lamella Skin Subcutaneous tissue Orbicularis oculi Tarsal plate Conjunctiva
